title: Cubs' Hammel to start Game 4, not Lester on short rest, Maddon says - CBSSports.com
text:
By David Brown | Baseball Writer 
Cubs will trail the Mets in the NLCS no matter what happens in Game 3, so bringing back left-hander Jon Lester to start Game 4 on short rest Tuesday is an option for manager Joe Maddon. He's still not going to take it. 
With his team behind 0-2 in the best-of-7 series, Maddon said at a press conference on Monday that right-hander Jason Hammel will be his man for Game 4 at Wrigley Field on Tuesday night. Lester, who pitched the series opener at Citi Field, presumably would be available for Game 5 the next day, if the series continues that long. 
(USATSI) 
During the regular season, Hammel posted a 3.74 ERA in 31 starts with a 172 strikeouts in 170 2/3 innings, but in the second half he had a 5.10 ERA and allowed an .856 on-base plus slugging. The other rested option for the Cubs would be Kyle Hendricks -- who allowed three home runs in Game 2 of the NLDS against the Cardinals -- but he also wasn't as good a Hammel in the regular season. 
Lester posted a 3.34 ERA in 32 starts during the regular season, his first with Cubs after signing a $155 million free-agent contract in the offseason. Lester came to the Cubs having earned a highly respected postseason reputation, but he has allowed 13 earned runs over his past 21 1/3 innings in the playoffs covering three starts -- reminding us that no one is a sure thing. Lester's career 2.85 ERA in 98 playoff innings remains sterling, but he's also never started a playoff game on fewer than four days of rest. 
If the Cubs used him that way in this series, Lester probably would have to make it a short outing, and it just might not be worth it to try. 
Hammel started the deciding Game 4 of the NLDS against the Cardinals, which the Cubs won 6-4 with Hammel throwing the first three innings. He allowed two runs, three hits and three walks before seven Cubs relievers finished. Hammel's overall results in the playoffs -- a 5.00 ERA in 18 innings over five outings with the Cubs, Athletics and Rays -- are a bit misleading. In 2012, he made a pair of starts for the Rays against the Yankees in the ALDS in which he allowed two runs over 5 2/3 innings. The Rays lost both of those games, but if Hammel gives the Cubs that against the Mets, they'll take it and run. 
(USATSI)
